Acid Mothers Temple.title: AMT calendar 2025 + Digital single
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O.
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
As a way of expressing our gratitude to our friends and ardent fans who have always been so kind to us, we are producing the ACID MOTHERS TEMPLE calendar, albeit in a very small number of copies.

We have been receiving more and more inquiries from overseas every year, so this year we have decided to sell a small number of copies via Bandcamp.

We also sell the Christmas songs recorded on the the COVID-19 pandemic as digital singles.

Acid Mothers Temple.title: Black Magic Satori
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple & Space Paranoid
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
[Acid Mothers Temple & Space Paranoid]

An Acid Mothers Temple unit formed in 2013 at the request of our Spanish booking agent, who wanted to see Acid Mothers Temple playing Black Sabbath. A new unit was duly formed and toured the Iberian peninsula. 

Originally the group's existence was to be limited to this one tour, however we realised that both AMT＆The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. and AMT＆The Cosmic Inferno had long moved beyond their original psychedelic heavy rock roots to play a wide range of music. So we decided to keep Acid Mothers Temple & Space Paranoid as a permanent unit that would focus just on spacey heavy rock. 

We were determined to draw a line between us and the many doom metal and black metal bands who have also been inspired by Black Sabbath. So, placing Sabbath back into the early seventies context of their birth, we have defined them as a British blues rock band. To this template we have added sixties psychedelic elements, as well as an improvisational approach (something that Sabbath virtually never do live), and we have attempted to reconstruct their songs in heavier and spacier way. The group will not limit itself to Black Sabbath covers, but will consider to explore the possibilities of ever spacier, ever heavier blues rock.



This is the only one studio album of Acid Mothers Temple & Space Paranoid. The group broke up in 2017.

The original LP was released by Safety Meeting Records, and the CD was released by Chaotic Noise Recordings in 2013.

This digital album was remastered for Bandcamp by Kawabata Makoto.

Acid Mothers Temple.title: AMT24
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O.
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
Acid Mothers Temple's discography is vast and can be likened to a labyrinth, so the band has released a 24-hour compilation album digitally that traces the history of the band.

However, it was impossible to cover all of their works in 24 hours, so we have compiled our works from the first album to 2007, a decade of work, in 24 hours.

For this release, Kawabata Makoto re-mastered all the songs and produced a special mix version.

At the end of the album, there is a new song from a new album by the current members and a rare live recording of a performance with Simeon (Silver Apples), who passed away 2020.

Acid Mothers Temple.title: AMT24 vol.2
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O.
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
Acid Mothers Temple's discography is vast and can be likened to a labyrinth, which is why the band has released digitally the second of a series of 24-hour compilation albums tracing the band's history.

However, it is impossible to cover all our work in 24 hours, so as a sequel to the last installment, this time we have compiled in 24 hours the 10 years of their work from "Acid Motherly Love (2007)" to "Astrogasm From The Inner Space (2014)".

For this release, Makoto Kawabata remastered all the songs and created special mixed versions.

The album ends with a new song from the limited lathe cut 7” EP by the current members.

Acid Mothers Temple.about: Acid Mothers Temple SWR, the most insane and superb power trio by Yoshida Tatsuya (Ruins) and Tsuyama Atsushi (ex. Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O.) and Kawabata Makoto in the history of Acid Mothers Temple, invites a free jazz saxophone player Umezu Kazutoki and Boredoms guitarist Seiichi Yamamoto for a crazy night of raging, completely improvised psychedelic sound mandala!
Acid Mothers Temple.credits:

Acid Mothers Temple.title: Acid Mothers Doravideo
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple with Ichiraku Yoshimitsu
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
Ichiraku Yoshimitsu (a.k.a. doravideo) joined Acid Mothers Temple @ "7th Acid Mothers Temple Festival" in 2008.

Ichiraku was a drummer of AMT in 2001 (he played on many AMT's albums, "In C", "New Geocentric World", "Absolutely Freak Out" and more...). Also he is a unique solo musician / media artist, at that time he used his drum kit as a video controller, controlling the video at the same time as he played.

This is live recording of Acid Mothers Temple with Ichiraku Yoshimitsu @ "7th Acid Mothers Temple Festival" in 2008.

The original CD was released by Acid Mothers Temple label in 2010.

This is the first time to digital reissue.

Acid Mothers Temple.about:
The original cassette tape was released by Nanjo Asahito's La Musica. (probably 1998 or 1999) 

the sources were incomplete demo recordings of early Acid Mother's Temple. Nanjo equalized and distorted to his trademark "Nanjo Sound".

When Kawabata got these tracks of this cassette tape, he remastered for upload on Bandcamp.

The tracks included here were later completed and included on the first cassette tape and the first album.

Acid Mothers Temple.about:
This is an unreleased live recording in Toronto 2015. It was the bassist / vocalist Tsuyama’s last North American tour. Also the present drummer Satoshima Nani’s first year.

This is rare that the band played new song “Benzaiten” from the new album, that’s why the band has never played this song after Tsuyama left from the band. In middle of the set, Nani broke his bass drum head completely, so he moved floor tom as bass drum in the end of the set.

This digital live album was released only for Bandcamp.

Acid Mothers Temple.title: Pink Lady A Go Go : Live in Lisbon 2022
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O.
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
The brand-new live recording from “MetaReboot Tour in Europe 2022”.

On this show, there was the strict regulation about maximum volume. Kawabata didn’t use one of his amp Roland JC-120, used only Marshall JCM-900. 

Kawabata had looked for any chance to play a kind of special set for a long time, finally the time was coming. The group played only 2 song for 55 min., “Pink Lady Lemonade” and “Cometary Orbital Drive” both songs are led by minimal guitar riffs, rhythm section (Satoshima Nani on drums and Sawano Shozo on bass) developed songs. They played like “minimal trance set”.

This digital live album was released for only Bandcamp.

Acid Mothers Temple.title: The Origin of Acid Mothers Temple
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mother’s Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O.
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
The original cassette tape was self-released in 1996. It was sold by Kawabata in an edition of 10 at a gig organized by Tsurubami’s drummer Emi Nobuko.

The cassette also featured a track called “Psycho Line”, but it was considered to be of inferior musical value and has been omitted from this reissue. 

In this time, an unreleased track “Big Foot Eva” was added as a bonus track.



Early jams dating from the dawn of Acid Mothers Temple, recorded in 1995 and early 1996. At the beginning they spelt the group’s name with an apostrophe (Mother’s) before later changing it to the current Mothers.

Acid Mothers Temple.title: Live in Tolosa [remastered]
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple et Rosina de Peira
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
The original dbl LP and CD were released by BamBalam Rercords in 2014.

This is the historical live recording of Acid Mothers Temple with the Occitan traditional singer Rosina de Peira. (It was second time to play together. The first time was in Toulouse 2002.)

“La Nòvia” is well known as Acid Mothers Temple’s cover of the Occitan traditional song. We discovered this song from Rosina de Peira e Martina’s “Ié (1982)” from Revolum.

Kawabata remastered for digital release on Bandcamp 2022.
Acid Mothers Temple.credits:

Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O.
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
This is an unreleased live recording in 2004. 

The venue was underground of a church, and no air-conditioning. Three bands played before us, the hall was already like a hell more than a sauna, too hot and sticky. We felt the sound was bended by too high temperature and humidity. It was the hottest and toughest show ever.

This original source is a VHS video tape that John Gibbon of Bardo Pond filmed.

This digital live album was released only for Bandcamp.

2004 is the first year a founder member / vocalist Cotton left the band, the bassist Tsuyama replaced her.

The founder member / drummer Koizumi Hajime came back to the tour line-up in 2004. (He is also a founder member of Mainliner too.)

This is really rare recording that Higashi Hiroshi plays guitar solo on middle part of “Pink Lady Lemonade”.

Acid Mothers Temple.title: Acid Mothers Temple 1995 - 1997 vol.1
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O.
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
This original cassette tape "Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. 1"was released for Mainliner US tour in Feb.1997.

And reissued on dbl LP by Synesthetic Recordings in Nov. 2007 as "The Early Acid Mothers Temple Recordings 1995 - 1997", then as a dbl CD by OHM Records/Synesthetic Recordings in Jun. 2016. 

This is the pre-1st album, some tracks are early version.



[ liner notes from reissue by Synesthetic Recordings]



In 1995 the quartet of Kawabata Makoto (Musica Transonic, Mainliner, Toho Sara), Koizumi Hajime (ex. Mainliner, ex. Seventh Seal), Suhara Keizo (Arijigoku, Rashinban), and Cotton Casino (Mady Gula Blue Heaven) formed a new group and started to record their improvised jam sessions. The group did not yet have a name at this point in their existence. A group of social dropouts of every description - musicians, dancers, artists, farmers, channellers, ex-yakuza, mermaid researchers and professional vagrants - known as the Acid Mothers Temple Soul Collective, had already begun to coalesce around Kawabata.



Several years earlier Kawabata had spent some time in a beatnik commune in Nagano, but he soon left, having become repulsed by their exclusionary left-wing ideology and hypocritical ecological activities. In response he had founded his own commune, one without any political ideology or ethics save that of non-interference in each other's lives. The mission of this "hometown of souls" would be to open its doors to anyone who was still searching for something in life.



Around the same time Kawabata had become involved in the Tokyo underground scene through his role as guitarist with Musica Transonic. Determined to do something to introduce the world to the other members of the Acid Mothers Temple Soul Collective, he decided to invite them to join his as yet untitled new improvising jam band. His old friend Higashi Hiroshi and many other members of the collective started to participate in the group's recording sessions. This would be the beginning of Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. (AMT).



In 1996 a limited edition cassette entitled Acid Mother's Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. (note that the band's name was spelled with an apostrophe in the beginning) was sold at an event that Kawabata played at. This was the first release to bear the AMT name, and it included recordings by the original quartet, an early take of "Speed Guru", and other recordings dating from 1995 and early 1996.



In 1997, Kawabata joined Mainliner on their US and European tour. He took with him two limited edition cassettes entitled Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. 1 and Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. 2, which were sold at gigs on the tour. They consisted of recordings from 1995 to 1997, including tracks by the original quartet with added overdubs and newly recorded tracks. After the tour ended, Kawabata went back to work on these pieces, mixing and adding new overdubs. These would eventually become the recordings that were released by PSF as the band's eponymous first album (PSFD-93), so the original cassettes may be considered as "demo" versions of that record.



While these early recordings were released under the AMT name, they were in fact closer in concept to Kawabata's solo albums. Recordings of improvised jams were manipulated using musique concrete methodology and remade into Kawabata's personal image of psychedelic music. There was no intention for the group to play live, and in fact there were no gigs in the first few years. But when the first PSF album was released, Kawabata decided to tour overseas for the first time in June 1998. Soon afterwards Tsuyama Atsushi joined the group, and began to cement its identity as a live band. The process of transformation from a Kawabata solo project into a group was one that began around this time and still continues today.

Acid Mothers Temple.title: Acid Mothers Temple 1995 - 1997 vol.2
Acid Mothers Temple.artist: Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O.
Acid Mothers Temple.about:
This original cassette tape "Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. 2"was released for Mainliner US tour in Feb.1997.

And reissued on dbl LP by Synesthetic Recordings in Nov. 2007 as "The Early Acid Mothers Temple Recordings 1995 - 1997", then as a dbl CD by OHM Records/Synesthetic Recordings in Jun. 2016. 

This is the pre-1st album, some tracks are early version.



[ liner notes from reissue by Synesthetic Recordings]



In 1995 the quartet of Kawabata Makoto (Musica Transonic, Mainliner, Toho Sara), Koizumi Hajime (ex. Mainliner, ex. Seventh Seal), Suhara Keizo (Arijigoku, Rashinban), and Cotton Casino (Mady Gula Blue Heaven) formed a new group and started to record their improvised jam sessions. The group did not yet have a name at this point in their existence. A group of social dropouts of every description - musicians, dancers, artists, farmers, channellers, ex-yakuza, mermaid researchers and professional vagrants - known as the Acid Mothers Temple Soul Collective, had already begun to coalesce around Kawabata.



Several years earlier Kawabata had spent some time in a beatnik commune in Nagano, but he soon left, having become repulsed by their exclusionary left-wing ideology and hypocritical ecological activities. In response he had founded his own commune, one without any political ideology or ethics save that of non-interference in each other's lives. The mission of this "hometown of souls" would be to open its doors to anyone who was still searching for something in life.



Around the same time Kawabata had become involved in the Tokyo underground scene through his role as guitarist with Musica Transonic. Determined to do something to introduce the world to the other members of the Acid Mothers Temple Soul Collective, he decided to invite them to join his as yet untitled new improvising jam band. His old friend Higashi Hiroshi and many other members of the collective started to participate in the group's recording sessions. This would be the beginning of Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. (AMT).



In 1996 a limited edition cassette entitled Acid Mother's Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. (note that the band's name was spelled with an apostrophe in the beginning) was sold at an event that Kawabata played at. This was the first release to bear the AMT name, and it included recordings by the original quartet, an early take of "Speed Guru", and other recordings dating from 1995 and early 1996.



In 1997, Kawabata joined Mainliner on their US and European tour. He took with him two limited edition cassettes entitled Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. 1 and Acid Mothers Temple & The Melting Paraiso U.F.O. 2, which were sold at gigs on the tour. They consisted of recordings from 1995 to 1997, including tracks by the original quartet with added overdubs and newly recorded tracks. After the tour ended, Kawabata went back to work on these pieces, mixing and adding new overdubs. These would eventually become the recordings that were released by PSF as the band's eponymous first album (PSFD-93), so the original cassettes may be considered as "demo" versions of that record.



While these early recordings were released under the AMT name, they were in fact closer in concept to Kawabata's solo albums. Recordings of improvised jams were manipulated using musique concrete methodology and remade into Kawabata's personal image of psychedelic music. There was no intention for the group to play live, and in fact there were no gigs in the first few years. But when the first PSF album was released, Kawabata decided to tour overseas for the first time in June 1998. Soon afterwards Tsuyama Atsushi joined the group, and began to cement its identity as a live band. The process of transformation from a Kawabata solo project into a group was one that began around this time and still continues today.
